metadata.notes: An Easter-themed sermon focusing on the existential anxiety of death and the promise of resurrection.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher uses shame-based comparisons regarding church attendance and 'confessing' status to coerce the listener into a specific mold of piety.
quotes: Some of you who are very lax in your regularity of worship do not know what a privilege it is...
Of how many of us can it be truthfully said that we are found guilty of being believers in Jesus?

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The preacher offers comfort regarding the loss of loved ones, though it leans toward a sentimental dependency on the 'Friend' (Jesus) rather than empowering the listener's own spiritual agency.
quotes: Is the ache when my mother goes never to be eased by reunion?
He... put his right hand upon John and said, 'Fear not.'

adult.analysis: While the preacher acknowledges philosophical arguments, he ultimately dismisses the Adult's capacity to reason ('Our minds play tricks on us') in favor of a Parent-Child dependency on authority.
quotes: This is one of those things... to which we cannot really reason our way.
We shall rest our final confidence upon the word and work of One...

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The sermon heavily leverages the 'Natural Child's' fear of death to force an 'Adapted Child' response of submission to the 'Champion' and the preacher's dogma.
quotes: I do not know how to die, but I have a Friend...

free_child_FC.analysis: There is a poetic, almost romanticized use of imagery (music, family tables, blazing eyes) that touches on the Free Child's sense of wonder, though it is quickly harnessed for theological compliance.

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher assumes the role of the 'knower' and 'protector' (Parent), addressing the congregation as vulnerable, fearful, and somewhat 'lax' children who need both a scolding and a rescue.
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: Socially, it is an Adult-Adult exploration of death; Psychologically, it is a Parent-Child transaction where the preacher uses the 'fear of death' to ensure the listener's 'Adapted Child' remains dependent on the institution/dogma.
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'double bottom' lies in the shift from acknowledging human grief (Adult) to shaming the listener's lack of commitment (Critical Parent) under the guise of 'Easter hope'.

detected_games.name: Bait & Switch / Redemption

formula_g_analysis.con: The promise of addressing the universal fear of death and the beauty of family love.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's existential dread and grief ('the empty chair').
formula_g_analysis.switch: Shifting from the 'lovely faith' to the 'terrifying fear' and then to the 'lax' behavior of the listener.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The listener feels small and dependent; the preacher feels secure as the bearer of the 'keys'.

evidence_quotes: Some of you who are very lax... do not know what a privilege it is.

detected_games.name: ITHY (I'm Only Trying To Help You)

formula_g_analysis.con: Offering a solution to the 'mystery of death'.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's inability to 'reason' their way out of mortality.
formula_g_analysis.switch: The preacher highlights the listener's failures (laxity, lack of 'confessing' status).
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The preacher maintains the role of the Rescuer while the listener remains the 'Victim' of death and sin.

evidence_quotes: I have a Friend who has keys and will unlock the door.

preacher_roles.rescuer: Dominant. The preacher presents the 'Champion' (and by extension, the sermon) as the only shield against the 'king of terrors'.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Secondary. Manifests when shaming the 'lax' congregants or those not 'guilty' of faith.
preacher_roles.victim: Minor. Hints at the preacher's own mortality ('we who preach here... stained with sin') to build a false sense of 'we are all in this together' before assuming the Parent role.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: Victim (of death, of their own 'lax' nature, and of their 'tricky' minds).
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: Minimal. The sermon suggests that the only way out is through total dependency on the 'Friend' rather than developing an Adult faith that integrates reality and hope.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: The sermon is a classic example of Parent-Child homiletics. While it begins with an Adult-oriented reflection on the human condition, it quickly devolves into a game of 'Bait & Switch.' It uses the universal trauma of death to bypass the listener's Adult ego and trigger the Adapted Child's fear and guilt. By discrediting reason ('minds play tricks'), the preacher ensures the listener cannot achieve autonomy and must rely on the 'keys' held by the religious authority. The shaming of 'lax' attendees further reinforces a Critical Parent dynamic that undermines the purported message of 'Faith Beyond Fear.'
strengths: Strong use of imagery to connect with the Free Child's emotions.
Effective identification of a universal human 'gimmick' (fear of death).
areas_for_improvement: High level of coercive 'Critical Parent' language.
Systematic undermining of the listener's 'Adult' ego (reason/logic).
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Address the congregation as Adult subjects capable of processing grief and hope. Instead of shaming 'lax' attendance, explore the 'Here-and-Now' value of community. Move from being a 'Rescuer' who holds the keys to a 'Fellow Traveler' who shares the Adult reality of faith.
